title: 112_s1873
content: The Act is titled the "Bonus Depreciation and Small Business Expense Extension Act" and includes an extension of bonus depreciation and temporary 100 percent expensing for certain business assets. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change dates for expensing and bonus depreciation. The Act extends the election to accelerate the AMT credit in lieu of bonus depreciation to 2014. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change dates for expensing and bonus depreciation. The Act extends the election to accelerate the AMT credit in lieu of bonus depreciation to 2014. Additionally, special rules for round 3 extension property are introduced, disregarding certain limitations and business credit increase amounts for taxpayers who previously elected acceleration. The taxpayer may elect not to apply certain rules to round 3 extension property, but if they do not make the election, the rules will apply. The taxpayer must compute and apply bonus depreciation amounts to eligible qualified property that is round 3 extension property separately from other eligible qualified property. Taxpayers who have not previously elected acceleration must follow specific rules. The taxpayer may elect to apply bonus depreciation to its first taxable year ending after December 31, 2011, and subsequent years if certain conditions are met. The paragraph applies to eligible qualified property, specifically round 3 extension property, defined as property eligible solely due to the extension of special allowance under the Bonus Depreciation and Small Business Expense Extension Act. The heading and clauses in section 168 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are amended to change dates from January 1, 2013, to January 1, 2014. The amendments in the Internal Revenue Code change dates from January 1, 2013, to January 1, 2014 for various sections. Effective date applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2011. Extension of increased expensing limitations for depreciable business assets and treatment of certain real property as Section 179 property. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend expensing limitations for depreciable business assets and certain real property as Section 179 property. Changes include adjusting dates from 2012 to 2013 and 2013 to 2014 for various provisions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend expensing limitations for depreciable business assets and certain real property as Section 179 property. The amendments include changing dates from 2013 to 2014 and from 2010 or 2011 to 2010, 2011, or 2012. These changes apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011.
